questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with intellectual disability is found to have bilaterally subluxated lenses. He also has a history of deep vein thrombosis. Physical examination findings are as shown in the image below. Which of the following vitamins will be the most useful in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows arachnodactyly and a positive wrist sign, indicative of marfanoid habitus. The presence of marfanoid habitus in a patient with intellectual disability, bilaterally subluxated lenses and a history of deep vein thrombosis points to a diagnosis of homocystinuria. The vitamin which can be used for treatment is pyridoxine (vitamin B6). Administration of large doses of pyridoxine (vitamin B6) restores the activity of the deficient enzyme in half of all cases of homocystinuria.

Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disease that is most commonly caused by a deficiency of the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an accumulation of homocysteine in the blood and a clinical syndrome of intellectual disability, subluxated ocular lenses, long and slender extremities, arachnodactyly and arterial and venous thrombi. The skeletal features of homocystinuria often mimic Marfan syndrome.

  Marfan syndrome Homocystinuria
Inheritance pattern Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Intellectual disability Absent Present
Vascular complications Aortic root dilation Thrombosis
Lens dislocation Superotemporal Inferonasal

 

Demonstration of elevated total homocysteine in the blood confirms the diagnosis. If there is a deficiency of cystathionine β-synthase enzyme, there will be elevated levels of methionine as well. 50% of the cases of homocystinuria are termed pyridoxine-responsive because large doses of pyridoxine can enhance the activity of deficient enzyme in these patients.

Folate supplementation is also added to overcome any folate deficiency which might occur due to increased conversion of homocysteine to methionine. For the other 50% of the patients, the treatment consists of methionine restriction and cysteine supplementation. In addition, betaine (methyl group donor), folate and vitamin B12 may also be added.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient presents with weakness and atrophy of the proximal muscles of the limb. He has a history of episodes of hypoglycemia since childhood. His serum lactate and uric acid levels are found to be normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with complaints of muscle weakness and hypoglycemia with normal blood lactate and uric acid levels, the most likely diagnosis is Cori disease. 

Cori disease (type III glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to a deficiency of the glycogen debranching enzyme. The features of Cori disease include hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and hyperlipidemia but with normal blood lactate and uric acid levels. Muscle weakness and atrophy can also occur in these patients. Liver biopsy shows the accumulation of glycogen in the form of limit-dextrins in hepatocyte cytosol and the presence of fibrous septa.

  Von Gierke Disease Cori Disease
Deficient enzyme Glucose-6-phosphatase Debranching enzyme
Hypoglycemia Present Present
Hepatomegaly Present Present
Renal disease Present (proteinuria, hypertension, renal stones) Absent
Blood lactate Elevated Normal
Blood uric acid Elevated Normal
Gluconeogenesis Impaired, since glucose-6-phosphatase is required in the final step of gluconeogenesis Intact

questions.text:
A newborn presents with poor feeding, vomiting, and hypotonia. The results of his laboratory investigations are as given below, prompting the suspicion of organic acidemia. Further workup reveals it to be propionic acidemia. Which of the following need not be restricted in this patient?
  • Blood glucose: 15 mg/dL
  • Arterial blood pH: 7.2
  • Serum ammonia: Elevated
  • Urine ketones: Positive
questions.solution:
In a newborn presenting with hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis with ketosis, and hyperammonemia, a diagnosis of organic acidemia is most likely. In patients with propionic acidemia and vitamin B12–unresponsive forms of methylmalonic acidemia, a diet low in valine, isoleucine, methionine, threonine, and odd-chain fatty acids is required.

Organic acidemias occur due to a deficiency of propionyl-CoA carboxylase (propionic acidemia) or methymalonyl-CoA mutase (methylmalonic acidemia). Amino acids like valine, isoleucine, methionine, threonine and odd-chain fatty acids are successively metabolized into propionyl-CoA, methylmalonyl-CoA and succinyl-CoA to give rise to citrate cycle intermediates. In the absence of the above-mentioned enzymes, organic acids accumulate and cause a variety of downstream effects.

They cause inhibition of gluconeogenesis, causing hypoglycemia, ketosis and high anion gap metabolic acidosis. They also inhibit the urea cycle, causing hyperammonemia. Patients usually present in infancy with vomiting, poor feeding, hypotonia and seizures. Treatment is mainly by reducing those substances in diet which can get metabolized to form propionyl-CoA or methylmalonyl-CoA. This includes valine, odd-chain fatty acids, methionine, isoleucine and threonine. Carnitine supplementation is also often required.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male newborn is admitted to the hospital because of lethargy and poor feeding. His condition progressively deteriorates and he is now in a coma. Serum ammonia levels are found to be elevated and urine shows the presence of orotic acid. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a male newborn presenting with features of hyperammonemia (lethargy, poor feeding, seizures) along with elevated serum ammonia levels and orotic aciduria is suggestive of ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) deficiency. 

OTC catalyzes the conversion of carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine to citrulline. OTC deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder. Clinical manifestations vary in severity from lethargy to encephalopathy and coma. Confirmatory tests for OTC deficiency include analyzing the plasma amino acid profile, which will show a low citrulline level, and increased glutamate and alanine. Urine shows the presence of orotic acid.

Other options:

Option A: Orotic aciduria occurs due to a defect in the enzyme UMP synthase (de-novo pyrimidine synthesis pathway). This leads to elevation of orotic acid in the blood and the urine. The clinical manifestations include failure to thrive, developmental delay, and megaloblastic anaemia refractory to folate and vitamin B12 supplementation. There is no hyperammonemia, which is seen in OTC deficiency. The treatment consists of administrating uridine to bypass the deficient enzyme. 

Option B: Propionic acidemia presents with hyperammonemia, hypoglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. There will be no orotic acid in the urine. 

Option D: Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency presents with hyperammonemia and hypoketotic hypoglycemia. There will be no orotic acid in the urine. 

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrics department with a history of passing foul-smelling and greasy stools. A small intestine biopsy was taken and is shown below. The peripheral smear showed acanthocytes. Which of the following is unlikely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with steatorrhea, acanthocytosis on peripheral smear and histopathological slide showing lipid-laden enterocytes is most likely to be abetalipoproteinemia. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disease. It is caused due to the mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP). MTTP is necessary to transfer lipids to nascent chylomicrons in the small intestine and to VLDL in the liver. In abetalipoproteinemia, there is an absence of chylomicrons, VLDL, LDL (apoB containing lipoproteins), and deficient levels of plasma cholesterol and triglycerides.

In abetalipoproteinemia, the usual presentation is fat malabsorption, diarrhea, and failure to thrive in early childhood. Vitamin E deficiency secondary to abetalipoproteinemia can lead to spinocerebellar degeneration. It manifests as loss of deep tendon reflexes, progressive ataxia, and lower limb spasticity by adulthood.

Intestinal biopsy shows lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium due to triglyceride accumulation. Accumulated lipids disappear after infants stop taking feed. Early treatment with supplemental vitamins, especially vitamin E, may significantly slow the development of neurological sequelae.

Acanthocytes (spur cells) are spiculated red cells with a few projections of varying size and uneven surface distribution. The image below shows acanthocytes in the peripheral smear.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presented to the ED with a history of severe retrosternal chest pain. His serum cholesterol levels were 380 mg/dL. Despite appropriate resuscitative efforts, the patient did not survive. The given image shows his abdominal aorta at the time of the autopsy. Which of the following correctly describes the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with grossly elevated serum cholesterol, accelerated atherosclerosis (as shown in the image of the aorta), and symptoms suggestive of myocardial infarction, a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (type II hyperlipoproteinemia) is likely. In this disorder, there is a reduction in the activity of the LDL receptor. 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to mutations that reduce the functioning of LDL receptors, the most common being a mutation in the LDLR gene itself. Physical findings present in some of the patients include tendon xanthomas (especially involving the Achilles tendons) and corneal arcus. These patients may have a myocardial infarction at a young age.

Diagnosis is usually established based on biochemical tests. LDL cholesterol >190 mg/dL or total serum cholesterol >300 mg/dL without any secondary etiology should point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. Homozygotes for the disease might have total serum cholesterol even up to 1000 mg/dL.

Treatment includes restriction of saturated and trans fats in the diet and high-intensity statin therapy. If adequate control is not achieved with statins alone, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor (Ezetimibe) or a PCSK9 inhibitor (Alirocumab, Evolocumab) can be added to the treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is defective in Zellweger syndrome?

choices.text: β oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids
α oxidation of unbranched fatty acids
β oxidation of medium chain fatty acids
ω oxidation of medium chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
Zellweger syndrome is due to defective biogenesis of peroxisomes. β oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids is defective in Zellweger syndrome.

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. Affected newborns show a typical facial appearance consisting of a high forehead, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, and epicanthic folds. They also have hypotonia and neonatal seizures. Patients with Zellweger syndrome often do not survive beyond the first year of life.

Defect in peroxisomal structure causes metabolic pathways which are exclusive to peroxisome to be affected. These include:

  • β oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids
  • α oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids (such as phytanic acid)
  • Synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens

There is currently no cure for Zellweger syndrome, and treatment is generally supportive and focused on managing symptoms and improving quality of life.

questions.text:
In a newborn with a deficiency of pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex, which of the following should be given in the diet?
  1. Fatty acids
  2. Isoleucine
  3. Leucine
  4. Valine
  5. Lysine
questions.solution:
Since pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex deficiency causes a defect in glucose utilization, ketogenic substances like fatty acids, and amino acids like leucine and lysine should be given in the diet.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex catalyzes the oxidation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, which then enters the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle for ATP production. A deficiency of this enzyme complex causes a buildup of pyruvate, which is then shunted to form alanine (via ALT) and lactate (via lactate dehydrogenase).

The disease is characterized by severe lactic acidosis and cystic lesions in the white matter of the brain. Giving ketogenic substances in the diet, such as fatty acids, leucine, and lysine decreases the blood lactate level in the patients. 

Related Pearl: Pyruvate metabolism

Fate of pyruvate

Converts alanine to pyruvate and vise-versa.
2 Pyruvate carboxylase Formation of oxaloacetate from pyruvate to be used in the TCA cycle
3 Pyruvate dehydrogenase Pyruvate to acetyl Co-A to be used in the TCA cycle
4 Lactic acid dehydrogenase Pyruvate to lactate(Anaerobic glycolysis)

questions.text: A deficiency of the enzyme which catalyzes the given step will lead to which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
The step marked in the given image, conversion of GM2 ganglioside to GM3 ganglioside, is catalyzed by hexosaminidase A. Deficiency of hexosaminidase A enzyme leads to Tay-Sachs disease.

Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder. It is characterized by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. Clinical features include progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, and a cherry red spot on the macula. There is no hepatosplenomegaly, as is seen in Niemann-Pick disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided flank pain and hematuria. The microscopic examination of his urine specimen is shown below. A diet low in which of the following amino acids could theoretically be beneficial for the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with right-sided flank pain, hematuria and hexagonal crystals on microscopic examination of the urine points to the diagnosis of cystine stones. A diet low in methionine may theoretically reduce the urinary excretion of cystine.

Cystinuria occurs due to a hereditary defect in an amino acid transporter in the renal proximal convoluted tubule and intestine. This prevents the reabsorption of amino acids like cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. The only known complication of this disease is the formation of calculi, because of the low solubility of cystine in the urine. Cystine is more likely to precipitate in acidic urine.

Prevention of stone formation in patients with cystinuria can be done by increasing fluid intake and alkalinization of the urine with sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate. Chelating agents such as penicillamine have also been found to be useful. Tiopronin is currently the best choice drug for cystine reduction, but side effects like nephrotic syndrome may limit its long-term use. A diet low in methionine may theoretically reduce the excretion of cystine in the urine by directly reducing its formation.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed to have a deficiency of the enzyme which catalyzes the given metabolic step. Which of the following statements is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Tandem mass spectrometry is the screening test of choice in newborns
Can present with macrocephaly and intellectual disability
Mainstay of treatment is low phenylalanine diet

questions.solution:
The enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine is phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to phenylketonuria. Phenylketonuria presents with microcephaly and intellectual disability.

Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism, due to the deficiency of an enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase or its cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the body fluids and the brain. The excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenyl ketones, namely, phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine.

Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odour in the skin and urine in PKU.

Other characteristic clinical findings include:

  • Affected infants are lighter in complexion
  • Neurological abnormalities like seizures, spasticity and hyperreflexia
  • Microcephaly and growth retardation

Tandem mass spectroscopy is the screening method of choice and a low phenylalanine diet forms the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a rash on sun-exposed areas of the body and a history of ataxia and diarrhea. His urine shows the presence of only neutral amino acids. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient with manifestations of pellagra (rash in sun-exposed areas, ataxia, and psychiatric manifestations) along with the presence of neutral amino-aciduria, a diagnosis of Hartnup disorder is the most likely.  

Hartnup disorder is an autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the transporter for neutral amino acids like tryptophan. Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss leads to its reduced bioavailability. This hampers niacin synthesis, and Hartnup disorder can thus present with manifestations of niacin deficiency (pellagra) like diarrhea, dermatitis and dementia.

The major clinical manifestation is cutaneous photosensitivity. The skin becomes erythematous after sun-exposure, and might develop a pellagra-like rash and eczema over time. Some patients might have intermittent ataxia manifested as unsteady, wide-based gait. Cognitive development is usually normal, but there may be episodic psychiatric manifestations such as irritability, emotional instability and depression.

The diagnosis of Hartnup disorder is established by typical clinical history and the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine. Urinary excretion of other amino acids remains normal, which differentiates it from causes of generalized aminoaciduria like Fanconi syndrome.

Indole derivates like indican may be found in large amounts in some patients due to bacterial breakdown of unabsorbed tryptophan in the intestines. This causes the Obermeyer test to be positive. Treatment with nicotinamide and a high-protein diet gives a good response in symptomatic patients.

questions.text: A baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of lethargy and poor feeding. On examination, it is noted that the urine had a smell of burnt sugar. A defect in which of the following enzymes causes this disease?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis, in this case, is that of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). This disease occurs due to a defect of the enzyme branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase.

MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to a deficiency of branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex. This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids valine, leucine, isoleucine, and alloisoleucine. These amino acids, particularly leucine and its metabolite accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain.

The affected child develops poor feeding and vomiting a few days after birth. There is a period of hypertonicity with a period of flaccidity in between. These appear as repetitive boxing and bicycling movements. The babies may also have hypoglycemia, but this is not corrected by the administration of glucose. The urine, sweat, and cerumen of the baby have a sweetish maple syrup-like odor.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Leucine levels are usually higher than isoleucine, valine, and alloisoleucine. Since the patient excretes ketone bodies in the urine, the urine will be positive for the dinitrophenylhydrazine test.

Treatment involves controlled intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine. Very high levels of leucine are removed by hemodialysis.

questions.text: A father reports to a pediatrician with his daughter stating that she has episodes of lethargy, irritability, and vomiting right after she drinks any fruit juice. Urinalysis after such an episode showed that Benedict's test is positive. Which of the following enzyme deficiency is likely?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with symptoms occurring after ingesting fruit juices (containing fructose) points to the diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance, and aldolase B enzyme deficiency seen here.

Fructose-1,6- bisphosphate aldolase/ aldolase B is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into triose phosphate and glyceraldehyde phosphate. It also hydrolyzes fructose-1-phosphate.

Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive condition, caused by pathogenic variations in the ALDOB gene which causes aldolase deficiency.

Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). It usually presents during infancy when sugar-containing feeds are introduced, but some patients (who are less sensitive) can present at older ages as well.

Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. Acute ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive, hepatic disease, kidney failure, and death.

Reducing substance is seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test positive) as fructose is a reducing sugar. Reduced levels of fructaldolase B activity in the liver and demonstration of two pathogenic variants in ALDOB on molecular genetic testing give a definitive diagnosis.

Treatment involves complete cessation of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.

The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose.

Other options:

Option B: Fructokinase converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate, the deficiency of which can give rise to essential fructosuria. Essential fructosuria is a benign, asymptomatic defect of intermediary metabolism characterized by the intermittent appearance of fructose in the urine.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphatase is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose and phosphate. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to von Gierke disease characterised by hypoglycemia, growth retardation, and hepatomegaly.

Option D: Hexokinases catalyse the first step in glucose metabolism, i.e, phosphorylation of intracellular glucose.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Blood glucose level was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine.

Option B: von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It will not be seen in newborns who are exclusively on breast milk.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient complains of reduced mobility of the spine & hip and knee joint pain. On examination, bluish-black discoloration of the sclera and ear cartilage was found. The thoracolumbar spine CT showed flattened & calcified intervertebral discs, and the urine sample turned black on standing. This condition is seen due to the deficiency of enzyme _______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alkaptonuria, caused due to the deficiency of homogentisate oxidase enzyme.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/ homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine.

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discolouration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. Ochronosis, which is bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue; generally occurs after the third decade of life and it occurs due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidation products like benzoquinone acetic acid in connective tissue.

Arthritis generally begins in the third decade. Arthritis often begins in the spine and resembles ankylosing spondylitis in its large-joint distribution. Radiographs of the spine showing flattened and calcified intervertebral discs are pathognomonic. Other findings include degeneration of the intervertebral discs followed by disc calcification and eventually fusion of the vertebral bodies. Osteophyte formation and calcification of the intervertebral ligaments also occur.

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria (shown below). The ferric chloride test will be positive.

The images below show pigmentation of the skin and an x-ray of the spine that shows calcification of intervertebral discs.

Other options:

Option A: Tyrosine transaminase deficiency causes type II tyrosinemia (Richner-Hanhart syndrome). Patients present with painful corneal erosions with photophobia, learning disability, and palmoplantar keratosis.

Option C: Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase deficiency causes type I tyrosinemia (Tyrosinosis). Patients generally present with failure to thrive, neuropathy, boiled-cabbage urine, and liver failure secondary to cirrhosis.

Option D: 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase deficiency causes type III tyrosinemia (neonatal tyrosinemia). Patients might rarely have a mental disability.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother with complaints of self-biting his lips and nails. On examination, the child has delayed developmental milestones, spasticity, and dystonia. Nail findings are as shown in the image below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing self-mutilation and laboratory values showing hyperuricemia is most likely suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan disease.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine leading to increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP). Increased PRPP leads to increased purine synthesis, which is later degraded to uric acid. Increased hypoxanthine is also converted to uric acid.

The patients have intellectual disability, behaviors of self-injury like lip and finger biting, developmental delay, muscle dystonia, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

Diagnosis is made by the elevated levels of uric acid and by HGPRT enzyme assay.

The image given below shows the metabolism of hypoxanthine and guanine by HGPRT.

Other options:

Option A: Autism mainly presents with problems in social communication and social interaction. They have poor verbal and non-verbal communication, absence of eye contact, repetitive behaviors like lining up toys or flipping objects, echolalia, etc. Intellectual impairment may or may not be present.

Option C: Patients with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) present with infections. Diarrhea, pneumonia, otitis media, sepsis, and cutaneous infections are common presentations. It is caused by various genetic mutations that lead to the absence of T and B-cell function. They have a low lymphocyte count.

Option D: Tourette’s disorder is characterized by sudden repetitive, non-rhythmic motor movements or sounds. They present with loud grunting or barking noises or shouting obscene words. Motor tics include tongue protrusion, sniffing, hopping, squatting, blinking, or nodding.

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Allopurinol
  • Febuxostat

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in a patient with McArdle's disease?

choices.text: Presentation in the first year of life

questions.solution:
McArdle disease, also known as type V glycogen storage disorder is an autosomal recessive condition. It typically presents during late childhood or in the second decade of life. The muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme deficiency interferes with ATP generation by glycogenolysis in the muscles. This causes muscle glycogen accumulation.

Symptoms are exercise intolerance associated with muscle cramps. A second-wind phenomenon where the symptoms subside after a short period of rest can also be seen. Myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis leads to the passage of burgundy-colored urine in some patients. 

Rarely, it can present during infancy as hypotonia, muscle weakness, and respiratory complications. It is generally fatal. Muscle biopsy to measure glycogen content is the standard diagnosis. Avoiding strenuous exercise prevents symptoms. Glucose administration before exercise can improve tolerance. Vitamin B6 is also recommended.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child has delayed developmental milestones and intellectual disability, with the following appearance (image A). On further examination, there is an enlarged tongue, cloudy cornea, and hepatomegaly. A radiograph of the hand is shown in image B. A girl born in their family also had similar symptoms and she died at 9 years of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Hurler syndrome. The child is 2 years of age and has coarse facial features like a depressed nasal bridge, thick lips, and an open mouth with protruded tongue. The radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpals and phalanges. These features along with severe developmental delay, cloudy cornea, hepatomegaly, and intellectual disability suggest that the child has Hurler syndrome.

Hurler syndrome is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) I. It is caused due to deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides.

Patients usually present between 6-24 months of age. They have

  • Intellectual disability
  • Skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex- thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged diaphyses of the long bones, macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella
  • Cloudy cornea, glaucoma, retinal degeneration
  • Mixed hearing loss, etc

Other options:

Option A: The Scheie syndrome is a milder form of MPS-I (MPS I-S ). The symptoms appear after 5 years of age and the diagnosis is made between 10-20 years. It is characterized by normal intelligence and stature, joint stiffness, aortic valve disease, corneal clouding, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option B: Hurler-Scheie syndrome is an intermediate between Hurler syndrome and Scheie syndrome. The onset of symptoms is between 3-8 years of age. They have mild or no intellectual dysfunction. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option D: Hunter syndrome is a type II MPS. It occurs due to the deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase. It shares the same features as type I MPS like coarse facial features, short stature, and dysostosis multiplex. However, there is no corneal clouding. It is the only MPS with X-linked recessive inheritance. So if a baby girl is affected in the family, it is less likely to be Hunter syndrome. All the other MPS are autosomal recessive.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child presents with mild diarrhea for the past 3 days. Today, he developed severe lethargy and had an episode of seizures. Laboratory testing reveals hypoketotic hypoglycemia. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes could produce this kind of test result?
questions.solution:
This child, with lethargy, seizures, and hypoketotic hypoglycemia, is likely to have medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase deficiency.

Medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency is a disroder associated with mitochondrial fatty acid beta-oxidation. It is one of the most common inborn errors of metabolism. MCAD is an important enzyme involved in fatty acid beta-oxidation, which is important in producing ketone bodies as an energy source when blood glucose levels are low.

It is usually diagnosed at birth during routine screening for disorders of the newborn. However, sometimes, it can be detected within the first two years of life. These babies present with vomiting that progresses to lethargy and seizures triggered by mild illness. The common laboratory results seen in these patients result from a failure to synthesize ketone bodies during episodes of hypoglycemia. Hence, the child will present with hypoketotic hypoglycemia.

The diagnosis can be confirmed with a combination of biochemical and genetic testing. This illness, once diagnosed, can be easily managed with small, frequent meals to avoid a state of hypoglycemia.

Other options:

Option B: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency can result in phenylketonuria. This is an inborn error of metabolism in which phenylalanine is unable to convert to tyrosine, resulting in the accumulation of phenylalanine. This results in the characteristic 'musty' odor of the urine and body fluids. These children can also present with seizures and hyperactivity. In fact, many of the symptoms result from increased phenylpyruvate (a ketoacid) derived from the buildup of phenylalanine in this condition.

Option C: UMP synthase is an enzyme deficiency that results in orotic aciduria. This disorder is an inborn error of pyrimidine metabolism that presents with developmental delay, failure to thrive, and possibly epilepsy. Laboratory testing reveals pancytopenia.  

Option D: HMG CoA reductase is an important enzyme involved in the synthesis of cholesterol. This enzyme is targeted by statins, which are prescribed in hypercholesterolemia and in patients at risk for cardiovascular events.

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.
